page.title: 19Hexton Wildlife and Animals
page.content: {Wildlife}flourishes in our area because trees, hedges and vegetation are abundant. We have seen 27 different kinds of birds.The rarest is the{kestrel}which we see over the Pegsdon hills and by the{bell tower}of Hexton church. The goldcrest is another rare visitor. We frequently observe blackbirds and sparrows. A pair of house martins nest under the school porch. Squirrels are common and moles frequently dig runs across playing fields and gardens. Rabbits and hares thrive in the fields, particularly in the nature reserves. A flock of sheep is kept in the hills and one of rare breeds is kept in the area. Bury farm has a herd of beef cattle and some dairy cows. Most farmers keep dogs, cats,chickens and horses for riding.
